|cpu1_cores = 1 |cpu1_type = MIPS 74Kc |cpu1_type_rev = (R2) |cpu1spd = 480 |is_doc = |bus = |flash1type = Serial |fla1_num = |fla1chip = Macronix;MX25L6405DMI-12G;MX B09423 25L6405DMI-126 36498400; |flash1size = 8 |flash1maxsize = 7929856 |ram1type = |ram1type1 = |ram1spd = |ram1size = 64 |ram1chip = Samsung;K4T51163QG-HCE6;946 K4T51163QG-HCE6 CJJ355P1C; |ram1_num = |nvramsize = 64 |eth_cpu = true |sw1chip = Broadcom;BCM5325E;BCM5325EKQMQ; |wan_ports = 1 |wan_speed = 100MbE |lan_ports = 4 |lan_speed = 100MbE |ethstandard = IEEE 802.3/3u |portbasedvlan = |802.1qvlan = |auto_mdix = |sup_jumbo = |ethoui = 20:4E:7F, 30:46:9A, E0:46:9A, E0:91:F5 |oui = 20:4E:7F, 30:46:9A, E0:46:9A, E0:91:F5 |bootwait = |stockbootloader = CFE;128kCFE;; |stockos = Linux;2.6.22;; |exp_if_types = USB 2.0 |exp_usb_num = 1 |usb_hub = |pwr_volt_type = VDC |pwr_vdc = 12 |pwr_amp_dc = 1.5 |pwr_conn = barrel |pwr_barrel_outer = |pwr_barrel_inner = |pwr_barrel_len = |pwr_pol = |serial = yes |jtag = yes |specialfeat = |flags = DFS |addchip = |802dot11_protocols = abgn |defaulip = 192.168.1.1 |defaultlogin = admin |defaultpass = password |defaultssid = NETGEAR, NETGEAR-5G |defaultssid_regex = ^NETGEAR$, ^NETGEAR-5G$ |default_ch = |manuf = Foxconn |manuf_model = U12H155 |manuf_rev = T00 |tpfirmware = DD-WRT, FreshTomato |availability = common |eoldate = |fccapprovdate = 04/01/2010 |estreldate = 09/01/2010 |reldate = |estprice = |upc = 606449071146 |ean = |dx_sku = |newegg = |asin = B0041LYY6K |asin_country = |asin2 = |asin_country2 = |countrymanuf = China |buttons = |led = Green/Amber/Blue |dimensions = 23 x 153 x 31 mm (8.8 x 6.0 x 1.2 in) |weight = |wi1_if_name = |rad1chip1cpu = true |rad1oui = |rad1_ant_conn = |rad1txchains = 2 |rad1rxchains = 2 |rad1sstreams = 2 |rad1stand = IEEE 802.11b/g/n |rad1n = 300 |rad1g = 54 |rad1b = 11 |rad1freq = 2.4 |rad1correv = 17 |rad1cap = ap sta wet led wme pio 802.11d 802.11h rm cqa mbss16 afterburner ampdu amsdurx amsdutx acktiming rxchain_pwrsave radio_pwrsave bcm_dcs |wi2_if_name = |rad2chip1 = Broadcom;BCM43224;BCM43224KMLG CA0942 P20 941256 4; |rad2oui = |rad2_ant_conn = |rad2txchains = 2 |rad2rxchains = 2 |rad2sstreams = 2 |rad2stand = IEEE 802.11a/n |rad2n = 300 |rad2a = 54 |rad2freq = 5 |rad2correv = 23 |rad2cap = ap sta wet led wme pio 802.11d 802.11h rm cqa mbss16 afterburner ampdu amsdurx amsdutx acktiming rxchain_pwrsave radio_pwrsave bcm_dcs }}{{TIDTOC|embedded}} ==Overview== *Simultaneous Dual-Band, 10/100 Mbps Ethernet (FE) The default SSIDs for the device are assumed to be '''NETGEAR''' and '''NETGEAR-5G'''. :OEM: ''[[Foxconn]] / Hon Hai / [[Ambit]]'' U12H155T00 ==Links of Interest== The device is in the [http://www.dd-wrt.com/wiki/index.php/Supported_Devices ''DD-WRT Supported Device'' table], and has its own [https://wiki.dd-wrt.com/wiki/index.php/Netgear_WNDR3400 wiki]. *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=79102&postdays=0&postorder=asc&start=0 On the '''DD-WRT''' forums] (test build on pg7) *[http://svn.dd-wrt.com/ticket/2358 ''WNDR3400 WiFi 5GHz LED'' doesn't flash with activity] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=446521 ''Netgear WNDR3300v2 and WNDR3400''] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=485036 ''GURU's Netgear WNDR3400'' update] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=91305 ''Netgear WNDR3400'' support] ==Flashing== {{Flashnotice}} ===Flashing DD-WRT=== {{DDWRTNotice|trailednv64k}} *[[dd-wrt-wiki:Supported Devices#Netgear|Supported 17567]] [http://cyberpunx.com/2011/11/installing-dd-wrt-on-netgear-wndr3400-n600/ Source] '''Step 1''': Backup your current router configuration #Login to your router… probably at http://192.168.1.1 #Find the maintenance group in the left menu and click on ‘Backup Settings‘ #Click the button labeled ‘Back Up’ You’ll be prompted to download a file, save it and stick it on your desktop or someplace safe in case you need it later. '''Step 2''': Download factory firmware (just in case!!) As a precaution, I chose to download the factory firmware ahead of time so I could have it on hand if this entire process fails and I need to revert everything. * Download: [http://support.netgear.com/ci/fattach/get/109/1311011828/redirect/1/filename/Firmware%20Recovery%20for%20Routers%20v1.1.pdf Recovery Instructions from Netgear] * Download: [http://support.netgear.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/17216 WNDR3400v1 Firmware] Note: These recovery instructions have not been tested by me, use at your own risk. '''Step 3''': Download the DD-WRT firmware Downloading via the normal DD-WRT process didn’t work out because it stated the router wasn’t compatible and therefore wouldn’t provide a link. There is now a WNDR3400 chk file included in the official SVN stream, you can browse the 12/08/2011 release files [ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/dd-wrt/Eko/V24-K26/svn17990/ here]. * Download: [ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/dd-wrt/Eko/V24-K26/svn17990/Specific/dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNDR3400.chk dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNDR3400.chk] '''Step 4''': Flash DD-WRT on to the router Before flashing the firmware on your router, it’s highly highly suggested to do a [[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|30-30-30 reset]]. You can find instructions for this here: http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=51486 Quoting from the “[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=51486 peacock]” thread in the DD-WRT forums: ::“Failing to do a hard reset and failing to wait after flashing are the two most common NOOB errors that lead them to a world of unnecessary dd-wrt pain! This is not a minor optional step. The firmware writes information to the Nvram. This step clears that information. If you don’t clear it properly, parts of the old information be present with the new firmware, which can make it not operate properly. Don’t cut corners. Doing it before you upgrade can be very important; a hard reset is not just for after upgrades.” After performing the [[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|30-30-30 reset]], log back in to the router and flash it via the web gui. #Do NOT use a wireless connection to upload firmware. Use a wired (LAN) connection. #Login to your router… probably at http://192.168.1.1 #Find the maintenance group in the left menu and click on “Router Upgrade” #Click the browse button and find [ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/dd-wrt/Eko/V24-K26/svn17990/Specific/dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNDR3400.chk dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNDR3400.chk] [[File:Cyberpunx 01.png|600px|center|alt text]] #Click the “Upload” button and wait for the process to complete. #After the process is done and the router reboots, you can connect to http://192.168.1.1 and should see DD-WRT loaded successfully. #Perform another [[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|30-30-30 reset]]. #After the reset procedue is done, login to the router and set a username & password. '''Step 5''': Upgrade to latest version of DD-WRT: Now we have DD-WRT running on our WNDR3400v1, we can upgrade to the latest release using the normal flash method via the web gui. With the latest release, I attmpted to load the “mega” file and it was a success… * Download: [ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/dd-wrt/Eko/V24-K26/svn17990/Generic-nv6xk/dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega-nv64k.bin dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega-nv64k.bin] The upgrade process is pretty simple at this point. Some suggest doing a hard reset before and after upgrading. Since I just did a hard reset after installing DD-WRT, it’s not really needed again unless you make some configuration changes before you upgrade. #Do a [[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|30-30-30 reset]] if you need to. #Do NOT use a wireless connection to upload firmware. Use a wired (LAN) connection. #Login to your router… probably at http://192.168.1.1 #Click on the Administration tab and then click on Firmware Upgrade: [[File:Cyberpunx 02.png|600px|center|alt text]] #Choose the option to Reset to Defaults after flashing. #Click browse and find [ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/dd-wrt/Eko/V24-K26/svn17990/Generic-nv6xk/dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega-nv64k.bin dd-wrt.v24-17990_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega-nv64k.bin] #Click the “Upgrade” button at the bottom of the page and wait…. #*The router will take a few minutes to upload the file and flash the firmware. During this time, the power light will flash. #*A new page will open confirming that the upload was successful. #*It’s advised to wait at least 5 minutes before clicking continue. #Do a [[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|30-30-30 reset]]. #After the reset procedue is done, login to the router and set a username & password. You should now see something like the screen below that shows the 17990 firmware loaded on your WNDR3400v1: [[File:Cyberpunx 03.png|600px|center|alt text]] I’ve been running this on my router for a couple of days and all the features I need are active and working. Your mileage may vary…. ===Flashing Tomato=== *[http://www.linksysinfo.org/index.php?threads/netgear-wndr3400-v1-beta-tomato-support.41510/ ''Netgear WNDR3400 v1'' - (beta) Tomato support] {{ombox | type = speedy | text = '''WARNING:''' '''This is highly beta Tomato version. This image may brick your router. Make sure you have serial cable to debrick router!!''' }} [[File:Netgear WNDR3400 TomatoUSB.png|600px|center|Netgear WNDR3400 v1 - (beta)Tomato support]] *[[#Flashing TomatoUSB|Beta]] * '''Note:''' Intial flash must be done from the OEM firmware. :If your running dd-wrt, revert to the OEM firmware first. # restore default settings # flash using tomato image via GUI # after flash leave router for 5–7 minutes until ping 192.168.1.1 will return # log into Tomato and first of all erase nvram!! # after erase 2nd radio will disapear. Dont panic :) Just make reboot one more time # log into tomato and Have fun TomatoUSB Support Details: :- both radios works :- usb works :- power led and usb led works correct :- wps and reset buttons works :- VLANs are not supported yet :- wireless leds may not work correct :- upgrade router via GUI will brick router!! Image: [http://tomato.groov.pl/download/K26/testing/WNDR3400v1/tomato-Netgear-3400v1-K26USB-1.28.RT-101.chk tomato-Netgear-3400v1-K26USB-1.28.RT-101.chk] ===Flashing OpenWrt=== {{OpenWrtTechData|https://openwrt.org/toh/hwdata/netgear/netgear_wndr3400_v1}} {{OpenWrtWiki|https://openwrt.org/toh/netgear/wndr3400}} 14.07 *[https://dev.openwrt.org/changeset/35323 ''WIP''] {{ombox | type = speedy | text = '''WARNING:''' '''This is highly beta OpenWRT version. This image may brick your router. Make sure you have serial cable to debrick router!!''' }} *'''So far tests indicate no WebUI, No Wireless, it has telnet access.''' Currently, there is a development version of OpenWRT for this router located :at: [http://downloads.openwrt.org/snapshots/trunk/brcm47xx/openwrt-wndr3400_v1-squashfs.chk /trunk/brcm47xx/openwrt-wndr3400_v1-squashfs.chk] Also, this is not beginner firmware. If you've never dealt with a console, avoid! To flash: # Do a 30/30/30 reset. # With the stock firmware, flash that build. # Do a 30/30/30 reset again. By default, OpenWRT does not include a web interface and as such, :must be installed using opkg or must be compiled with it included. Telnet is available. Once the password is changed, telnet becomes :unavailable and ssh becomes available. Support for this model is still in development so not everything works. :The build linked above is using kernel version 3.6 as of this writing. I've been told that 3.8 works much better for it. Unconfirmed however. Wireless is disabled by default. To enable, type in the console: uci set wireless.@wifi-device[0].disabled=0 ==Upgrading== {{Upgrade dd-wrt}} ==Reverting== ===Reverting to OEM Firmware from OpenWrt=== ===Reverting to OEM Firmware from TomatoUSB=== # flash ofw image via GUI # after flash router wuill brick and power led will blink green light # flash ofw image one more time using tftp client # after flash make 30-30-30 reset Original image: [http://tomato.groov.pl/download/K26/testing/WNDR3400v1/WNDR3400-V1.0.0.50_20.0.59-OFW.chk WNDR3400-V1.0.0.50_20.0.59-OFW.chk] ===Reverting to OEM Firmware from DD-WRT=== :Per Eko There is simple way to flash original firmware. :-with router running dd-wrt, telnet in, do "mtd erase linux", wait until finished (2-3 min), then type "reboot" :-now router waits for new firmware - tftp the original .chk file (with your PC set to static IP 192.168.1.10 etc) :-when tftp transfer finishes, wait 3-4 min... ==JTAG-Serial Info== ===JTAG=== ====JTAG Pinouts==== J14 - '''DO NOT HOOK UPTO J10''' 
 nTRST  1o o2  GND
   TDI  3o o4  GND
   TDO  5o o6  GND
   TMS  7o o8  GND
   TCK  9o o10 GND
 nSRST 11o o12 N/C
'''Using [[TechInfoDepot:JTAG/TIAO/Universal JTAG User Manual (Parallel)|Universal JTAG Adapter]]''' 
  white  1o o2  black
    red  3o o4  GND
   blue  5o o6  GND
  green  7o o8  GND
 yellow  9o o10 GND
 orange 11o o12 N/C
===Serial=== ====Serial Pinouts==== '''JP1''' = 3.3v TTL Serial, 115200/8/N , 1 row of six pins 
 GND 6 o
 RX  5 o
 N/C 4 o
 N/C 3 o
 TX  2 o
 VCC 1 o
this setup was tested on the 3/20/2013, some other websites are showing the RX and TX opposite and this why does not work for this type of router ====Serial Recovery==== :As of March 2013 #After Setting up the Putty session, power up your router with the USB serial TTL cable you should see some info scrolling on the screen, press control-c rapidly and it will come with a promt CFE> #type on this prompt tftpd to start the tftpd server, you should see the message saying the command START TFTP SERVER and the message READING::: ts ready to send the new firmware. #assuming you have download the latest Firmware from Netgear do the following, open a cmd terminal and go to the folder you have save the firmware, type the following : tftp -i 192.168.1.1 put FIRMWARE_FILE.chk, you should see some comments about this on the putty session like reading processing and programing. #the router will start itself give it some time until finish it took me a while to sort out this router but i finally did it doing it this way. {{/Serial info}} ==USB Info== {{USB dd-wrt}} {{USB TomatoUSB}} ==Vlan Info== ===DD-WRT Vlan Info=== *[[TechInfoDepot:DD-WRT/VLAN Support]] Testing Needed ==Pictures==

[[Has images::fcc| ]] ==Notes== Known GPIO pin support: :gpio enable 0 - Turns on 5 {{abbr|GHz|gigahertz}} blue :gpio disable 0 - Turns off 5 {{abbr|GHz|gigahertz}} blue :gpio enable 2 - Turns off USB :gpio disable 2 - Turns on USB :gpio enable 3 - Turns power light to green :gpio disable 3 - Turns power light off :gpio enable 7 - Turns power light to orange :gpio enable 7 - Turns power light from orange off ===DD-WRT Notes=== The WNDR3400 CVNA (Cablevision edition) default username and password is admin/optimum ==Hardware Modification== WNDR3400v2 model will feature the BCM5358 chipset. ====Antenna Mod==== File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_a.jpg| File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_b.jpg| File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_c.jpg| File:Netgear WNDR3400 v1.0 AM d.jpg File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_e.jpg| File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_f.jpg| File:Netgear_WNDR3400_v1.0_AM_g.jpg| ==See also== *Netgear WNDR3400v1 *[[Netgear WNDR3400v2]] ([[Netgear WNDR3400v2/nvram]]) *[[Netgear WNDR3400v3]] ([[Netgear WNDR3400v3/nvram]]) [[Category:English Documentation]]
